questions.text: 5 people out of 60 who landed from an international flight were positive for COVID-19. Totally, 75 people were in contact with these 5 cases, out of these 15 were found to be positive within 2 weeks of the incubation period. Calculate the secondary attack rate in this?
questions.solution:
The secondary attack rate, in this case, is 20%

In this scenario, the total number of primary cases were 5.

The total number exposed people who were in contact with the primary cases were 75 and the total number of exposed people developing the disease were 15.

Secondary attack rate=(Number of exposed people developing the disease within the incubation period/Number of people exposed)×100

=(15/75)×100

=(1/5)x100

=20

Therefore the secondary attack rate is 20%

 

Note:

The incubation period of COVID-19 may extend up to 14 days, with a median incubation period between 4-5 days from exposure to symptoms onset.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: In a village with a given population, the total number of births in a year is 5100. There were 100 stillbirths. 25 newborns died within the first 7 days of life whereas 175 died due to various causes between 8 – 28 days of life. There were 50 deaths between the age of 1 month to 6 months of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Neonatal mortality rate = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year

The total live births in this scenario is 5100 – 100 = 5000 live births.

NMR = (25+175) x 1000/5000 = 40.

Note: Still births and deaths after 28 days of life are not considered in Neonatal Mortality Rate.

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: The biological value of a food substance is 800 and its digestibility coefficient is 12. Calculate its Net Protein Utilization and identify the food substance.
questions.solution:
96 and the food substance is an egg.

NPU = (Biological value of a food substance x Digestability coefficient) / 100 = (800x12) / 100 = 96. 

Eggs have the highest NPU value and that is why it is considered as a reference protein. 

Few Important food substances whose NPU is to be remembered:

(Different books give different value, these values are mentioned considering Park's textbook of Preventive and social medicine, 25th edition)

  • Egg - 100
  • Cow milk - 75
  • Meat - 80
  • Rice - 65
  • Groundnut/ pulses - 50

Net protein utilization is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body concerning nitrogen intake.

Note: The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Egg contains all nutrients except Carbohydrates and Vitamin C.

A 60 gm egg contains:

  • 6 g Fat
  • 6 g Protein
  • 30 mg Calcium
  • 1.5 mg Iron
  • 70 Kcal Energy

The cholesterol content is 250 mg/ egg. Egg protein has all 9 Amino acids needed for the body in the right proportions and hence it is considered as "Reference Protein". A boiled egg is nutritionally superior to raw egg. Boiling destroys avidin, a substance that prevents the body from absorbing Biotin.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: While examining a pregnant woman, you measure her fundal height to be 32 cm and the station of the fetal head is at -2. What could be the probable weight of the fetus?
questions.solution:
The fetal weight in the above case is 3.1Kg.

In the above case, fetal weight can be estimated using Johnson's formula. Height of uterus is 32cm, the station is –2 implying the head is above the ischial spines. Therefore, it is calculated as follows: [32-12] x 155 = 3100 grams = 3.1Kg

Estimation of fetal weight:

  • Johnson’s formula: This is only applicable in vertex presentation.
    • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
    • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams
  • Sonography: Fetal weight has been estimated by combining a number of biometric data, e.g. biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC) and femur length (FL), using the following formulae:
    • Shepard’s formula
    • Hadlock’s formula.

questions.text:
In a village with 200 eligible couples, family planning data of contraceptive methods is as follows:

Vasectomy – 30 Tubectomy – 30 IUD users – 12 Oral pill users – 30 Condom users – 18

What is the couple protection rate in the village?
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

In this scenario, a total of 120 couples out of 200 eligible couples are using contraceptive methods.

Therefore, CPR = (120/200) x 100 = 60% 

Eligible couple: It refers to a currently married couple, wherein the wife is at the reproductive age, which is generally assumed to lie between the ages 15 and 45 years.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: 32 grams of bleaching powder was required to disinfect 1820 liters of well water. When measuring the chlorine demand with the below-given apparatus for this well water, which cup would have shown the blue color after adding the indicator?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Horrock's apparatus used to measure chlorine demand of water, 4th cup would have shown blue color for it to require 32 grams of bleaching powder to disinfect 1820 liters of well water.

Since 1820/455=4, the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is 32/4=8 grams

To calculate the dose of bleaching required to disinfect 455 liters of water, the formula is (n×2). As we know the dose required, we have to calculate 'n' (n represents the position of the cup which was first to show the color).

8=n×2, therefore n=4.

The fourth cup would have turned blue on adding the indicator.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A drug trial compares the effect of a drug compared to placebo in decreasing cholesterol levels in 2 groups of 500 individuals each. A side effect to be studied simultaneously is the elevation of creatine kinase due to rhabdomyolysis. 10 individuals who received the drug develop this side effect, while only 5 individuals who are on placebo have this side effect. Calculate the number needed to harm (NNH).
questions.solution:
The number needed to harm (NNH) for this particular drug is 100.

The number needed to harm is given as the number of individuals we need to treat, to encounter an effect or side-effect of a particular drug. The higher the NNH, the better is the drug.

For example, if we see a side effect of a drug in 1 out of every 100 patients we are treating, it is better as compared to encountering 1 side effect after treating 10 patients.

The NNH to harm is 100 and 10 respectively in these cases, and the former drug is better because it has lesser side effects.

NNH is calculated as 1/absoulte risk increase (i.e. 1/ARI).

Step1: Calculate the risk of side effects with the drug as well as placebo

The risk with drug = 10/500

The risk with placebo = 5 /500

Step 2: Calculate the absolute risk increase:  ARI= side effect with drug-side effect even with placebo

10/500 - 5/500 = 5/500 = 1/100 = 0.01

Step 3: Calculate the NNH

1/ARI = 1/0.01 = 100

questions.text: The fasting blood glucose levels of a  group of diabetics were found to be normally distributed with a mean of 110 mg /dL and a standard deviation of 10 mg /dL. From this data, it can be inferred that approximately 99% of diabetics will have their fasting blood glucose levels within the limits of ____.
questions.solution:
In this scenario with a mean blood sugar level of 110mg/dL and a standard deviation of 10mg/dL, 99% of diabetics will have their fasting blood glucose levels between 80-140mg/dL.

99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean. This proportion is true for every normal distribution. Thus, we have to add and subtract 30 (three standard deviations = 10 x 3) from the mean to arrive at the limits within which 99% of the population would have their blood sugar, i.e., mean ± 3 SD which will be 80 and 140 mg.

The standard deviation is the most frequently used measure of dispersion. Range and mean are the other measures. The shape of a frequency distribution is determined by the standard deviation and mean which in turn depends on the individual observations. A frequency distribution with a symmetrical, bell-shaped curve is known as a normal distribution. It is also known as Gaussian distribution.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: A known amount of inulin and Evans blue dye is injected into a healthy woman of 60 Kgs. The volume of distribution of inulin was found to be 10L and the volume of distribution of Evans blue dye was found to be 2.5L. Which among the following is true regarding the volumes of various body fluids in this woman?
questions.solution:
In this woman, the interstitial fluid volume is 7.5 L.

In the above scenario, the volume of distribution of Evans blue, which measures the volume of plasma is 2.5 L. The volume of distribution of inulin, which measures the extracellular fluid is 10 L. 

Therefore,

Interstitial fluid volume = Extracellular fluid volume - Plasma volume

= 10L- 2.5L

= 7.5 L

Other volumes

About two-thirds of the total body water is present as intracellular fluid and one-third are present as extracellular fluid. Therefore, intracellular fluid will be approximately 2 times the extracellular fluid, which is around 20L. The addition of extracellular fluid with the intracellular fluid will give total body water, that is 20L+ 10L = 30L

The total body fluid is distributed mainly between two compartments, the extracellular fluid, and the intracellular fluid. The intracellular fluid is about two-thirds of the total body water and the extracellular fluid (ECF) is about one-third of the total body water. The ECF is divided into the interstitial fluid and the blood plasma. Interstitial fluid is about three-fourth of the ECF and blood plasma constitutes about one-fourth of ECF.

In an adult man, total body water is 60% of the total body weight whereas, in a woman, the total body water is 50% of the body weight.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

Related Pearl: Indicators for measurement of body fluids

questions.text: An epidemiologist is calculating the incubation period for measles in children aged 2 to 14 years. He was assigned a rural area with a sizeable portion of unvaccinated children and adolescents. He takes the sample size as 100. The median incubation period is 10 days, and the standard deviation he obtains is 4. What will be the standard error in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The formula for standard error is SE = standard deviation/ square root of sample size.

In this scenario, the standard error = 4/10 = 0.4.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: A patient's ECG strip is given below. His cardiac output was found to be 4.8 L/min. What is the stroke volume?
questions.solution:
Cardiac output is calculated by the following formula -

Cardiac output = Heart rate x Stroke volume

The patient's cardiac output is 4.8L/min.

His heart rate can be calculated from the rhythm strip given i.e., HR = 300/number of large squares between consecutive beats. There are approximately 5 large boxes between beats in this ECG.

HR = 300/5 = 60 beats/min.

Therefore, the patient's stroke volume = CO/HR = 4.8L/min/60 beats/min = 0.08 L = 80ml

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient has the following laboratory findings: pH 7.2, plasma sodium 136 mEq/L, chloride 110 mEq/L, bicarbonate 15 mEq/L, and potassium 2.6 mEq/L. Urine studies show a pH of 5.1. Following the administration of intravenous sodium bicarbonate, the urine pH is 5.8. Which of the following conditions is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The laboratory findings are most likely suggestive of type II (proximal) renal tubular acidosis.

The arterial blood gas analysis shows normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA).

Interpretation:

Step 1: The pH is 7.2 (<7.35) suggestive of acidosis

Step 2: Plasma bicarbonate is 15 mEq/L indicating metabolic acidosis

Step 3: Assessment of the anion gap:

 Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

= 136 - (110 + 15)

= 136 - 125

= 11 mEq/L (Normal range: 8-12 mEq/L)

Hence, the laboratory findings are suggestive of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Renal tubular acidosis is one of the common causes of NAGMA. The serum potassium is low (hypokalemia), suggestive of either type I or type II renal tubular acidosis. Type III RTA is rare and is seen mostly in children, while type IV RTA is associated with hyperkalemia.

The urine pH is initially 5.1 (<5.5, acidic), which increased to 5.8 (>5.5) following administration of sodium bicarbonate (alkali therapy), suggestive of poor bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules of the kidney, making the diagnosis of type II (proximal) renal tubular acidosis.

Type II RTA is commonly caused due to generalized proximal tubular dysfunction, associated with Fanconi syndrome (glycosuria, aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia). The bicarbonate is poorly reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule, leading to its increased excretion (bicarbonaturia). This leads to decreased plasma bicarbonate levels and metabolic acidosis.

As the plasma bicarbonate levels fall below the renal threshold for reabsorption of the HCO3- in patients with type II RTA, all the bicarbonate is reabsorbed thus maintaining the urinary pH acidic (<5.5). When sodium bicarbonate is administered intravenously, it increases the plasma bicarbonate levels above the limited renal threshold, leading to increased excretion of HCO3- causing increased urinary pH (> 5.5).

Alkali therapy for correcting plasma bicarbonate in type II RTA should be carried out with caution, as sudden increased availability of HCO3- to the distal tubules stimulates the secretion of potassium, further exaggerating the hypokalemia. Hence, potassium salts are usually administered along with alkali therapy. An oral solution of a combination of sodium and potassium citrate is commonly prescribed alkali therapy for this reason.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A clinical pharmacologist is studying the effect of the first-pass metabolism on the systemic availability and absorption of the drug 'X'. Drug 'X' is an oral formulation whose experimental absorption value was predicted to be 1. Hepatic clearance determined for this drug is 60L/ kg/hr. Considering the normal hepatic blood flow in a healthy individual to be 90L/kg/hr, calculate the systemic bioavailability for Drug 'X'.
questions.solution:
The systemic bioavailability of this drug is 33%.

The systemic bioavailability (F) of a drug is based on the extraction ratio (ER) and the extent of absorption of the drug (f).

F = f x (1-ER)

Extraction ratio is the parameter used to express the effect of hepatic first-pass metabolism on the drug.

ER = CL(liver clearance) / Q (Blood flow to the liver)

Thus, ER = 60 / 90 = 0.67

In the given question f= 1.

Thus, F = 1 X (1-0.67) = 0.33 OR 33%

questions.text:
You are a part of a research team working on a new rapid diagnostic screening test for COVID. The following table shows the results of 10,000 people who took the new screening test. Calculate the positive predictive value of this screening test.
  Disease - Present Disease - Absent
Screening test - Positive 40 20
Screening test - Negative 100 9840
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value of this screening test is 66.6%. Positive predictive value implies the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having the disease. 

This is calculated using the following formula :

(TP/TP+FP) x 100

where,

TP - True positive (Screening test and diagnosis is positive for the disease)

FP - False positive (Screening test is positive but the diagnosis is negative)

In this scenario :

(40/40+20) x 100 = (40/60) x 100 = 0.666 x 100 = 66.6%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text:
A patient is undergoing the estimation of p-aminohippuric acid (PAH) clearance. He was infused with PAH and the plasma and urinary concentration were measured. It shows the following values-
  • Concentration of PAH in urine: 14 mg/mL
  • Urine flow : 0.7 mL/min
  • Concentration of PAH in plasma- 0.02mg/mL

Which of the following is the correct conclusion? (GFR- glomerular filtration rate, ERPF- Effective renal plasma flow)
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the effective renal plasma flow (RPF) is 490mL/min. 

Clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which a particular substance is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes). Para aminohippuric acid (PAH) is filtered by the glomeruli and secreted by the tubular cells. Therefore, the amount of the PAH that enters the kidney is almost completely removed. It means that the entire renal plasma is cleared from PAH in a given time. Because of this reason, PAH clearance measures the renal plasma flow.

The formula used to calculate PAH clearance (CPAH) is:

 UPAH × V ⁄ PPAH  where,

UPAH - Concentration of PAH in urine- 14mg/mL

PPAH - Concentration of PAH in plasma- 0.02mg/mL

V - Urine flow- 0.7 mL/min

Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

PAH clearance =  UPAH × V ⁄ PPAH ,

= (14 x 0.7)/0.02

= 9.8 / 0.02

= 490 mL/min.

In an actual scenario, about 90% of the PAH is removed by the kidney. Therefore this is called effective renal plasma flow. Actual renal plasma flow is calculated by dividing the PAH clearance with an extraction ratio. The extraction ratio is arterial concentration minus renal venous concentration divided by arterial concentration. Normally the extraction ratio is 0.9.

If we consider the extraction ratio to be 0.9 in this scenario, the actual renal plasma flow will be

= 490/0.9

= ~544 mL/min

Similarly, inulin and creatine clearance is used in the measurement of the glomerular filtration rate.

questions.text: You are a molecular biochemist working on genetic elements and the organization of human recombinant chimeric DNA (cDNA). In a sample of extracted DNA element, you determine the percentage of thymine residues to be 22%. What would be the expected percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 28%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species,

Purines = Pyrimidines

Sum of purine = Sum of pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 22%, therefore adenine is also 22%.

Hence adenine + thymine = 44% and Guanine + cytosine = 56%. 

No of Guanine = No of Cytosine, so the percentage of cytosine = 56/2 = 28%.

Chimeric DNA (also known as recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant.
 
The practical applications of recombinant DNA technology include:
  • Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
  • Producing proteins such as:
    • Interferons, tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
    • Insulin, growth hormone
    • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)
  • Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • Gene therapy and stem cell therapy

questions.text: 400 mg of a drug was administered to a patient, of which 40 mg is excreted in 60 minutes. Assuming the drug follows first-order kinetics, how much of the drug would remain after 2 hours?
questions.solution:
After 2 hours, 324mg of the drug will remain.

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

In the given question, 40 mg out of 400 mg is excreted in 60 minutes ---> 40/400 = 0.1 fraction is eliminated every 60 minutes.

After 60 minutes; 400 mg - 40 mg = 360 mg remains 

The next 60 minutes (after 2 hours) = 360 * 0.1 = 36 mg is eliminated and 360 - 36 = 324 mg remains.

Simpler way -

  • 1/10 fraction is excreted in 60 minutes → 9/10 remains after 60 minutes.
  • 2 hours (120 min) is 2 times of 60 minutes.
  • So 400 * (9/10)(9/10) = 324 mg remains after 120 minutes.

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A student was asked to record ECG by using bipolar limb leads. The below image shows the arrangement of the bipolar electrodes and the potentials recorded across lead I and lead II. What is the potential recorded across lead III?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven’s law, the potential recorded across lead III is +0.7 mV.

Einthoven’s Law: Einthoven’s law states that if the ECGs are recorded simultaneously with the three limb leads, the sum of the potentials recorded in leads I and III will equal the potential in lead II.

Lead I potential + Lead III potential = Lead II potential

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (1.2-0.5) = +0.7 mV.

Note: Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary triangle drawn around the area of the heart. It is formed by the arrangement of three bipolar limb leads (the two arms and left leg).

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed at 5 minutes after birth. He is found to have a heart rate of 110bpm, coughs on stimulation, and has a strong cry. His limbs are well flexed, the body is pink, but extremities appear blue. The Apgar score for this newborn is ______
questions.solution:
The Apgar score for this newborn is 9.

In this baby:

  • Body pink, extremities blue: score 1
  • Heart rate, >100 beats/min: score 2
  • Coughs on stimulation, score 2
  • Well flexed of the extremities: score 2
  • Strong cry: score 2

Thus the total score is 9.

  • At 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth of the infant, the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.
  • A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition.
  • An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text:
A male patient was brought to the emergency room after a road traffic accident. He produces unrecognizable sounds only, opens his eyes only to a painful stimulus and his right pupil alone is unreactive to light. His posture on the bed is shown below. What is this patient's calculated GCS-P score?

GCS-P: Glasgow coma scale - pupils.
questions.solution:
The above patient has a GCS-P score of 6 which is calculated as follows.

The score for eye-opening - opens only to painful stimulus - 2
The score for verbal response - sounds only - 2
The score for motor response - decorticate posturing - 3
Pupillary score - one pupil non-reactive - 1

GCS-P score - 

It is the Glasgow Coma Scale score with the incorporation of pupillary function. The pupillary function was added so that the brainstem function is also represented by the score. 

The total score is calculated by adding the score for eye-opening, verbal, and motor responses and subtracting the pupil score from the sum.

Total score = 2 + 2 + 3 - 1 = 6

Decorticate posture:

  • The upper limbs are flexed, the lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

  • 9-12 represent moderate injury

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.
